	In my assessment, the IMF estimate is almost certainly going to be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report. The IMF has since released a January 2021 World Economic Outlook Update to account for policy support and vaccines to increase economic activity (IMF, 2021). Due to the support of the international community in combating COVID-19, economic relief and activity has increased and the market has adapted to redirect the course of economic growth over 2021. With the ability to obtain the COVID-19 vaccines becoming widely available soon, the impact to the economy has softened and thus allowed for a stronger recovery in the market (IMF, 2021). Policy implementations such as providing for households, providing resources for healthcare facilities, and economic policies to limit persistent damage have all aggressively combatted the damage of COVID-19 (IMF, 2021). The 15% No estimate in my assessment pertains to the impact of differing strains of the COVID-19 virus. While the vaccines have proved to be effective in most sectors, if a new strain of the virus is not combatted effectively by the virus, more research, containment strategies, and economic recovery programs could stall the hopeful outlook outlined in the January 2021 World Economic Outlook Update (IMF, 2021). Reference: IMF. (2021, January 01). World Economic Outlook Update, January 2021: Policy support and Vaccines expected to LIFT ACTIVITY. Retrieved March 07, 2021, from https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update

The IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 will be higher. Due to the covid-19 vaccine rollout, there is a more positive outlook for the world GDP. CNBC states that “the institution now excepts the global economy to grow 5.5% this year – a 0.3 percentage point increase from October’s forecasts” (Amaro, 2021).  https://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/imf-downgrades-outlook-global-economy-face-virus-71426050#:~:text=For%202021%2C%20the%20IMF%20envisions%20a%20rebound%20in,percentage%20point%20weaker%20than%20in%20its%20April%20forecast.

In January 2021, the IMF put out an updated World Economic Outlook. This updated report states “After an estimated 3.5 percent contraction in 2020, the global economy is projected to grow 5.5 percent in 2021 and 4.2 percent in 2022. The estimate for 2020 is 0.9 percentage point higher than projected in the October WEO forecast. This reflects the stronger than-expected recovery on average across regions in the second half of the year. The 2021 growth forecast is revised up 0.3 percentage point, reflecting additional policy support in a few large economies and expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year, which outweigh the drag on near-term momentum due to rising infections” (IMF 2021, p. 5).  Additionally, in late 2020 the “OECD projects global GDP to fall by 4.5 percent this year before growing 5 percent in 2021” which leads me to confidently predict that the IMF April 2021 report will be higher than October 2020.  International Monetary Fund. (2021). World Economic Outlook Update. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update
Richter, F. (2020). Global GDP could return to pre-pandemic levels as early as 2021, says OECD. https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/09/oecd-global-gdp-pre-pandemic-level-2021-sustainable-resilient/

Probability: 97% The IMF’s October 2020 Report projected estimated world GDP growth for 2021 was 5.152% (“World Economic Outlook Databases”). Since the time of this projection, the IMF released a World Economic Outlook Update, in January 2021. In it, they revised their latest World Economic Outlook Growth Projection to 5.5%, a revision up ~0.3% relative to the previous forecast, reflecting expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year and additional policy support in a few large economies (“World Economic Outlook Update”). One of the key policy drivers for this upward revision was the “more ambitious stimulus plans of the new U.S. Administration and Congress,” which could “raise U.S. GDP growth by another 1.25%” (Smith).  The IMF’s Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that the outlook remained uncertain, citing concerns about different strains of the virus and the slow rollout of vaccines across most of the world. In her words, “It is going to be a long and uncertain ascent” (Shalal). If additional, more deadly strains of the virus emerge, this could dramatically impact the accuracy of this projection. Another important factor that the IMF is relying on for their projections is policy support. Biden’s American Rescue Plan was passed by the US House of Representatives on February 27, 2021 (Biden). On March 6, the Senate passed the stimulus bill (“H.R. 1319”), moving the possibility of additional stimulus one step closer to spending an additional $1.9 trillion on pandemic and economic recovery. All signs point to the IMF’s estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 being higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report. Sources: Biden, Joseph. “Remarks by President Biden on the American Rescue Plan.” The White House. February 27, 2021. https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2021/02/27/remarks-bypresident-biden-on-the-american-rescue-plan/. Accessed March 5, 2021. “H.R.1319 - American Rescue Plan Act of 2021.” Library of Congress. https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319. Accessed March 5, 2021. January 24, 2021. https://money.usnews.com/investing/news/articles/2021-02-24/imf-chief-urges-strong-g20-action-to-reverse-dangerous-divergence-in-global-economy. Accessed 
March 5, 2021. Smith, Geoffrey. “Crude Oil Prices Rise as IMF Raises Growth Outlook.” Investing.com. January 26, 2021. https://ca.investing.com/news/commodities-news/crude-oil-prices-rise-as-imf-raises-growth-outlook2341128. Accessed March 5, 2021. “World Economic Outlook Databases.” International Monetary Fund. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/SPROLLS/world-economic-outlookdatabases#sort=%40imfdate%20descending. Accessed March 5, 2021.

"In our latest World Economic Outlook, we are projecting global growth for 2021 to be 5.5 percent, which is 0.3 percentage points above our previous forecast. And then growth is expected to moderate to 4.2 percent in 2022. The upgrade is owing to positive effects that have come upon with the onset of vaccinations in many countries and also because of the additional fiscal policy support that has been provided in some economies like the US and Japan." Says Gita Gopinath, the Economic Counselor, and Director, Research Department, IMF.  Since the data is already published in the January report, I expect that the April 2021 report will yield similar predictions. The presence of new variants of the COVID-19 virus poses a level of uncertainty for the world, but with the vaccination being distributed, the outlook is much better than in 2020. "We are in a race between mutating virus, and vaccinations and a lot depends on the outcome of this race", says Gopinath.    https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2021/01/28/tr012621-transcript-of-the-world-economic-outlook-update-press-briefing#:~:text=In%20our%20latest%20World%20Economic,to%204.2%20percent%20in%202022. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update

America's labor market serves as a good litmus test for analyzing the global economy. Unemployment is particularly helpful in determining the outlook of global futures. The US labor market recovered faster than expected with a unemployment rate of 6.9% reported in OCT2020. However, the true state of employment will emerge once the heavy government aid subsides (Curr, 2020). The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) projected that all G-20 countries, other than China, would experience a recession in 2020 as a result of the pandemic. The global GDP will not return to pre-pandemic levels until Q3 2021. While the OECD projections differed from November 2019 to September 2020 given the sharp dip caused by the pandemic lockdowns, the rate of growth remain largely the same (World Economic Fund, n.d.). However, the global GDP is not expected to extend above pre-pandemic levels until 2022. The continuance of the pandemic and associated economic impacts have suppressed economic predictions going into 2021 (Ritcher, 2021). In June, 2020, the IMF  reported a 1.9 percent decrease in economic growth as compared to its April, 2020 predictions. For 2021, the IMF forecasted a 5.4 percent growth in GDP, which is 6.5 percent lower than the predictions made in January 2020 prior to the pandemic (IMF, 2020). In October, 2020, the IMF projected a 5.2 percent growth in world GDP for 2021.  A primary factor in analyzing the world's economic recovery timeline is linked to the roll out of the vaccine. In October, 2020, the timeline for roll out was debatable. Since then, vaccines are becoming available and economic uncertainty is becoming more clear. Also in October, 2020, US unemployment was 6.9 percent. By January, 2021, unemployment fell to 6.3 percent. As vaccines offer more opportunity for economies to open, then the labor market is likely to benefit thus increasing the potential for GDP growth. Overall, vaccine confidence and falling unemployment rates below that which was anticipated will increase the potential for a higher projection for GDP growth in 2021. However, the continuance of government aid and realization of long-term economic scars present the potential to temper positive projections.  Curr, H. (2020, November 16). Governments Must Judge if the Economic Recovery Needs More Help: The Economist.  https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2020/11/16/governments-must-judge-if-the-economic-recovery-needs-more-help International Monetary Fund. World Economy to Trail Pre-Pandemic Trajectory for Years. Statista. https://www.statista.com/chart/22924/global-gdp-projections-made-before-and-during-covid-19-pandemic/ World Economic Forum. (n.d.). Global GDP Could Return to Pre-Pandemic Levels as Early as 2021, Says OECD. https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/09/oecd-global-gdp-pre-pandemic-level-2021-sustainable-resilient/

According to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and others, the global economy will experience growth in the near future. IMF made a statement that “amid exceptional uncertainty, the global economy is projected to grow 5.5 percent in 2021 and 4.2 percent in 2022” (World Economic Outlook Update). In comparison to the previous estimate, the 2021 prediction has been raised by 0.3 percentage point. Indicating that the expectations for a vaccine-driven boost in development later this year, as well as additional policy support in a few advanced economies. So with this knowledge there is a 95% chance for the GDP growth to be higher in April 2021.

The IMF has already posted an updated report this year, stating the following: “Amid exceptional uncertainty, the global economy is projected to grow 5.5 percent in 2021 [...] The 2021 forecast is revised up 0.3 percentage point relative to the previous forecast, reflecting expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year and additional policy support in a few large economies” (IMF, 2021). In addition, just last week China set an increased goal for their GDP growth in 2021 (China rebounds with economic growth target above 6%, 2021). Therefore, leaving the (extremely low) possibility of an impactful, unforeseen world event, there is almost a 100% chance that the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 will be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report, as it already personally reported that the outlook has been revised to a higher projection. Since the October 2020 issue of the World Economic Outlook, the IMF released a January 2021 World Outlook update which projects the global economy to grow 5.5% this year. The report states that the growth is a recovery from 2020’s severe collapse, revised by 0.3% from the previous projection of 5.152%. This 0.3% increase reflects “expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity”. The recovery will vary across countries and regions, dependent on access to medical interventions, effective policy support, and infection spillovers from other countries. Despite the toll of the pandemic on the economy and people, economic activity is adapting. There are, however, risks to this outlook. If progress is slower-than-anticipated and there is a struggle to contain the virus and vaccinate people, this could weaken confidence and lead to withdrawn policy support. Growth is going to depend on vaccine rollout and the incidence of COVID-19 infections. Though, it is expected that therapies will gradually become more widely accessible during 2021-2022. By the end of 2022, local transmission of the virus will be brought down to lower levels everywhere. The April 2021 growth estimate will be higher than the estimate provided in the October 2020 report. Compared to the January 2021 update, the April 2021 estimate could become higher due to the increasing accessibility to vaccines worldwide. I give the scenario a possibility score of 99%.

According to a World Economic Outlook (WEO) Update published by the IMF in January 2021, the IMF notes that “policy support and vaccines expected to lift activity,” revising its previous 2021 forecast of estimated world GDP growth from October 2020 from 5.152% to 5.5.%. It does note that its prediction is clouded in uncertainty, complicated by hopes from vaccine approvals and concerns from new virus variants, but that its increase of 0.3. percentage points reflects “expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year and additional policy support in a few large economies.” I believe that the predictions that IMF will make in its April 2021 WEO report will depend on the success of vaccine rollouts, country policies aimed at economic recovery, and multilateral cooperation to aid low-income developing countries in recovery over the next month. These things are hard to forecast, but with new vaccines being administered and distributed each day, countries aimed at reigniting their economies, and rising international cooperation to distribute vaccines to low-income countries, I expect the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 be higher in its April 2021 World Economic Outlook report relative to its October 2020 report. Additionally, the WHO  There are factors that could cause the estimate to decrease, such as international conflicts, rapid spread of COVID variants, or evidence of vaccine failure, which is why I am leaving a 2% possibility of a decrease, but I do not foresee any major changes occurring within the next month before the April 2021 report is released.

The IMF predicted a 5.5% growth for 2021 and 4.2% for 2022, this is due to the rollout of COVID vaccinations and some of the lessening of the grip of the pandemic. This will more than likely instill faith in their next estimate compared to the one in October.

The IMF released an update in January of 2021 projecting a .3% growth relative to its October 2020 report (https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2021/01/26/2021-world-economic-outlook-update). With vaccinations continuing well and with increasing production, the world will more quickly return to prepandemic levels of economic output, particularly in the U.S. which makes up a large percentage of the world’s GDP. As well as China, showing a projected 8.3 percentage growth and India showing a 11.5 percentage growth in 2021. This projected percentage increases show strong confidence that the April 2021 world GDP growth in the Work Economic Outlook will be much higher than the October 2020 report.

Seeing what is happening in the 10 year treasury repo market, with such colossal short selling that it went to -4.25% (which is supposed to be impossible), and March is going to be very turbulent in the financial markets. Keep in mind that the 10-year Treasury is The benchmark for a lot of things in the stock market and for mortgages. He is trying to reassure markets and doesn't want to draw attention to what a lot of people don't look at. The only thing not making me go to 0% is that I don't trust IMF economists to see what is coming, and if they do see it coming they may not want to panic the market with a bad forecast. Chairman Powell recently stated that he doesn't see inflation going above 2% for another three years which is a clear lie to try to calm the markets, it is obviously going to go above 3% this year and market sentiment is that it's going to 3.3%.  for those people who don't know what the repo market is, this is a way for banks to get overnight money by pledging assets as collateral. When an asset brings a negative yield out of repo market that means that so many institutions are putting up 10 year treasuries as collateral that they are willing to get a negative amount of money back. no rational investor would do this unless they are desperately trying to get 10-year treasuries off their books. This means major financial institutions are expecting the 10 year treasury to crash very soon, and this is something that is a benchmark for most of the economy. Just to be clear, the world economy cannot handle 3.3% inflation and the rising interest rates that go along with that. This is going to be worse than 2008. The risk is an overheated economy which moves the Fed to tighter policy, which generally results in recession, the US having no history even once of a soft landing.  Powell today says easy money still appropriate. Stock market down on this news.  Overall, things look rosy. What could change this is a market crash. Edging lower in case this volatility keeps up.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has in fact already published an update in January 2021 which increased its estimate for world gross domestic production (GDP) growth from 5.152% to 5.5%, citing development of vaccines against coronavirus and effective policy support to recovery efforts.  A few pandemic related concerns raised in the update include further spread of coronavirus and logistical challenges to vaccine distribution.  According to the John Hopkins global tracker, global daily cases have slightly decreased since the new estimate, returning to levels like those seen in October 2020.  Also, Google’s calculation of available data shows that ten times as many people are fully vaccinated as there were on 26 January 2021 and almost three times as many people have received at least one dose of the vaccine.  Furthermore, the recent U.S. Food and Drug Administration emergency use authorization of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine should provide additional optimism for the April estimate.  One other risk previously identified was the impact of a “no-deal Brexit”, which the latest report dismisses due to the December agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union.  Based on these factors, I predict with almost certainty that the IMF will maintain an estimate higher than 5.152% for global GDP growth in the April report.  I have assigned a 97% chance for this to occur, with only a 3% chance based on the possibility of issues in the efficacy of some vaccines or the rapidly increased spread of the virus due to early lifting of pandemic restrictions.

I am improving my forecast from 65% to 75% confidence that the IMF estimate for global GDP growth for 2021 will be higher in April 2021 than what was forecast in Oct 2020 report (5.152%) due to two recent reports: one from Goldman Sachs in which it raised its US GDP forecast by 0.5% to 6.4%, and one from Morgan Stanley which raised its global GDP forecast from 5.9% to 6.4%. The Morgan Stanley report that we are now entering the self-sustaining phase of the V-shaped recovery initially projected in 2020. This assessment directly conflicts with the initial worries this past fall that the pandemic will have a bigger impact on private-sector risk appetite and, hence, global growth; however, experts say that consumers have driven the recovery. To continue progress in economic recovery, the reports state that 3 key factors will characterize the next stage: synchronized global growth, an emerging-market rebound, and the return of inflation. So I will be looking for these indicators in news/reporting to determine whether my confidence will increase or decrease in the coming weeks.  Goldman Sachs also increased its US economic growth forecast for 2021, as Democratic officials make it more likely to see a larger stimulus package adopted in the first quarter of 2021. Unemployment is also projected to decrease to 4.8% in 2021. Although the U.S. GDP growth is only one part of the overall global GDP, I think it's still an indicator. Overall, my confidence is still discouraged by the news on the virus front, namely the slow pace of vaccination rollouts and and the emergence of additional infectious virus strains, and the affect this will have on spending, restrictions, and economic recovery despite the stimulus.
GDP for April 2020 may include momentum from 2019, all the economy shock was really accounted from March 2020 to date.
Everybody so high? Isn’t the situation and outlook worse then in 10/2020?

Looks like consensus by analyst is 5.4% for 2021 [1]

[2] https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/goldman-sachs-raises-us-gdp-forecast-for-2021/2102968

I forecasted with 65% confidence that yes, the IMF estimate for world GDP growth for 2021 will be higher in its April 2021 report than the 5.152% it estimated in its October 2020 report. I am cautiously optimistic that the IMF's estimate will increase in its next report since October because we have gained a clearer picture of COVID-19 spread and the roll-out of vaccines was ahead of expectation. There are many advanced economic nations that have had positive monetary policy responses. I also think there will be a stronger global, internationalized response to combatting the virus in 2021 than there was in 2020. However, I am tempering my positivity because it is unknown just how much lasting damage the pandemic has inflicted on the global economy, from shutting down businesses, unemployment, government intervention to bail out. It is also unknown how rapid the virus recovery can take place in emerging and developing economies compared to advanced economies.

The IMF growth forecasts, both from October for the next year and from April for the current year, appear to be statistically biased only in that they, in common with other forecasts, underestimate the likelihood of a recession (http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.587.9776&rep=rep1&type=pdf). Having just had a recession, a new one's unlikely in the next three months (https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0232615 implies <1% chance), so I'll base probability estimates on other forecasts released since October 2020.

The IMF's October 2020 forecast of 5.152% is slightly lower than the average of more recent forecasts, with the OECD's December forecast being 4.2% (https://www.oecd.org/economic-outlook/), Fitch's 5.3% (https://www.fitchratings.com/research/sovereigns/world-gdp-recovery-to-strengthen-from-mid-2021-on-vaccine-rollout-07-12-2020), Morgan Stanley's 6.4% (https://www.morganstanley.com/ideas/global-economic-outlook-2021), Citi's 5.0% (https://www.citi.co.in/portal/pdf/annual-outlook.pdf), and Consensus Economics' November forecast 5.9% (calculated from a PWC average, https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/research-insights/economy/global-economy-watch/projections.html). Those forecasts are consistent with their prior versions (2.8 - 5.2% by the OECD in June, http://www.oecd.org/economic-outlook/june-2020/, 5.2% by Fitch in September, same link as prev.), so neither vaccines' better-than-expected performance nor worse-than-expected late-Autumn case numbers seem to have dominated other effects on growth forecasts, but indicators like the OECD's CLI provide indications that might make those more recent forecasts closer to the IMF April forecast (https://www.econstor.eu/handle/10419/180842). Supposing recent forecasts are iid around the best possible estimate of the IMF's April forecast with current data, the mean of these forecasts will be taken from an approximately normal distribution, with maximum-likelihood underlying mean 5.4% and standard deviation 0.4%. In that model, there's a 70% chance that this best possible estimate of the April forecast is higher than the IMF's October forecast.
Vaccine development much further ahead of schedule than predicted in their October report - impacting on GDP recoveries from Covid-19 pandemic.

A majority of the forecasts that have come out from reputable institutions since October that I could find are higher than the IMF's. Not all, but most. So my base rate was a bit better than 50/50 for an upward revision.  It *looks* to me like the superforecasters are somewhat bullish, but a) I had to translate their version of the question into ours (they're asked 2021 relative to 2019 and b) there seem to be two versions of the question with different estimates, so I'm not sure I can put much weight on their numbers right now.  Vaccine news since October has been significantly good which is worth a big bump up in my estimate. And while the new, faster-spreading strain could increase Q1 lockdowns, in the US there's actually been some divergence between consumer spending and lockdowns, leading me to think that the GDP hit from lockdowns is slowing a bit over time. Finally, the US passed another relief bill which will keep consumer spending up.  All that together I came here at about 70 and seeing this group tilting in the same direction I'm upgrading my forecast, up to 82.

It looks like the test thresholds are going to change as the the vaccine is rolled out. The WHO just released a paper acknowledging that PCR tests with high cycle thresholds can have false positives. This opens the door for all jurisdictions to ensure that their testing thresholds are flow the levels that can create false positives. This information has been known for a long time. The New York times reported on it in the summer. Dr Fachi acknowledged it several months ago. Previously I believe it was believed by the authorities that having false positives was beneficial because it was better to err on the side of caution and it helped to justify stronger lockdowns. Now that the vaccine is being distributed changing the test threshold amounts will help it look like the vaccine is working, restoring public confidence. Florida has recently required its testing centers to report what their cycle thresholds are I believe that this will be a trend among all jurisdictions, which will lead to many fewer positive test results.
I got nothing on this one, but sometimes nothing is a cool hand according to Luke

Ok so after seeing how out of consensus my prediction was, i went and had a look at the actual performance of IMF forecasts.
available for download here: https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjZza7yp9ftAhWB2KQKHZrxAXEQFjATegQIIRAC&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.imf.org%2Fexternal%2Fpubs%2Fft%2Fweo%2Fdata%2FWEOhistorical.xlsx&usg=AOvVaw1a2MKXkNESwR0xsRUlR4Iw Since the question is about the last FY GDP growth forecast for 2021 before the year starts and the first of the year itself, i gathered these two datapoints for the global economy for every year since 1991. For good measure i also added the number of the last report published that still included this year so
FY t-1 Fall, FY t Spring and FY t+2 Fall On average the FY t-1 Fall is 0.38 percentage points ABOVE FY t Spring.
In 61% the last outlook of the year before was revised downwards in the subsequent year.
I would say this mostly confirms my earlier intuition about the IMF's optimistic bias* with regards to the evolution of subsequent projections. 1 So in terms of base rates i stand by my earlier take. 2 In terms of what "improved" in september vs now:
maybe somewhat more optimistic on vaccine availability but to pinpoint when an eocnomy will reopen, there's not much difference to having 10% vs 20% of people vaccinated by let's say april. as long as not enough people are vaccinated/immune, social distancing measures will remain in place.
in that sence, improvements in vaccine availability need to "tip a scale" (or "not fall below a certain level" rather) and i don't think the newsfeed there materially changed the outlook of the timing for herd immunity, and by consequence the end of social distancing. somewhat lower mobility than expected in Q4 2020 but mostly we knew this was coming? 3 In terms of what i think will improve between now and april:
i don't really know >>> so all in all i guess i think shifting growth from 2020 to 2021 is the main change since the fall-outlook and i doubt this will more than offset the imf's optimistic bias so i will actually double down on my take here and move to a 1/3 * i then went and checked FY t-1 Fall vs FY t+2 Fall (so the "actuals") and here on average the outlook in the year before is of byNEGATIVE  0.25%points, slightly more than half of the cases are overestimations.
I did the same exercise for FY t Spring vs FY t+2 Fall and ended up with an average error of POSITIVE 0.13%points and 43% cases were there was too much optimism.
I revised my beliefs accordingly :)

Forecasting a forecast, if I hadn't committed to this challenge I would be avoiding this one.  The IMF report was published on 7th of October so realistically the latest data included should be that of September 2020. Compared to September the news on vaccines is more positive, and mobility graphs (https://covid19.apple.com/mobility) have trended down, "theoretically" pushing more growth from 2020 into 2021. 
The Oct 20 report growth estimate of 5.2% reflected "a moderate downturn projected for 2020 and [was] consistent with expectations of persistent social distancing" and a "level of global GDP in 2021 [that] is expected to be a modest 0.6 percent above that of 2019. (https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2020/09/30/world-economic-outlook-october-2020 executive summary). 
So while I don't see any reason for them to change their moderate downturn projection in 2021, their persistent social distancing expectation should lessen.  I am projecting the over, but with limited conviction (60%), especially as we have only had 4 years in the last forty with growth above 5.2% (www.imf.org/external/datamapper/NGDP_RPCH@WEO/OEMDC/ADVEC/WEOWORLD).

An over/under on the IMF forecasting algorithm, this is a loser. Note to self: you should of turned around and walked away.  
The IMF forecast is a baseline and then it has upside and downside scenarios.  In october the forecasters (I think) would not have included first quarter lockdowns as stringent as in  1 Q 2020.  So  potential on the downside revision just based on what is occurr in December.  There is minimum historical data for a global synchronized recession for a forecaster to prepare a reliable model to make a future prediction about the rebound strength.   Basically theyare relying on past precedent of no recession last greater than 12 months and the recovery is robust in the first quarter of the recovery  and continues on for three quarters following.  The 2009 recession demonstrated that recessions can expand and u-bottom or flatline.  There are other unknowns like the impact of lifting of payment moratoriums on consumers (rent and education bills), rebuilding of savings rates, informal economy activity access to money and materials, moving foreign workers back to the countries employing them, and recovery in oil comsumption.  To conclude all these unknowns makes me lean to the under.

The effects of the debt and business closings from the government response to the virus have yet to fully hit us.
Although projections are now trending -0.2 percentage points below the IMF June projection.Growth is still projected to rebound in 2021 to 5.2 percent,
Reflation and snap back will revive growth forecasts.

%5.15 is too pessimistic given the recent news. Global growth averages at about %2.5 per year and there is likely to be a little over %4 contraction in GDP in 2020, making for an especially low base rate. That means world GDP is about %6.5 below trend, and it only needs to gain less than half of the distance back to the trend line in order to do better than the IMF forecast. Recovery in monthly data measuring economic activity is strong; such as PMI, other measures of manufacturing output and unemployment. The shock appears to not be very persistent. The vaccine news, which was not available as of October 2020, should also improve the situation. I think a lot of people are being misled about the current macroeconomic outlook by drawing inappropriate analogies to the Great Recession or the Great Depression, even though the data we have available is showing a much faster recovery. Despite this optimistic outlook, however, one must be mindful of tail risks in the forecast. Low growth years are by no means rare and the next year could turn out to be one due to bad luck. Based on my ground estimate of the frequency of sufficiently below average performance in global growth, I'm setting a forecast of %80 for now.
